Award.AwardTitle: Non-Asymptotic Random Matrix Theory and Geometric Functional Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research is intended to provide new connections between two areas of mathematics, probability and functional analysis. One of the main objects of investigation is a random matrix, a large rectangular array of random data. The PI strives to understand the properties of such arrays which hold with high probability and the dependence of those properties on the nature of random entries and the structure of the matrix. This study will have potential applications beyond the realm of pure mathematics, as random matrices are used in statistics, computer algorithms, and wireless communication. Another direction of the proposed research is the study of high dimensional convex sets with the emphasis on their complexity and approximation. This research will also have computer science applications including rate estimates for various high-dimensional algorithms.


One of the main directions of this research is the non-asymptotic theory of random matrices, a new and rapidly developing area of research analyzing spectral characteristics of a random matrix of a large but fixed size and striving to obtain bounds valid with high probability. The PI intends to study singular values, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors of different ensembles of random matrices of a large size. The results obtained in this direction would have important applications within the random matrix theory in proving limit laws for the spectral characteristics of random matrices. Another group of problems comes from geometric functional analysis, an area of mathematics concerned with the study of high-dimensional convex bodies and normed spaces. A progress in this direction would lead to better understanding of the structure of sections and projections of such bodies, as well as possibility of approximation of a general convex body by a body with certain nice properties. Both directions have a significant component related to the theoretical computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit of the PI's research.


Within the framework of this project, the PI worked on problems in two different but interrelated areas of mathematics: random matrix theory and geometric functional analysis. Random matrices are large rectangular arrays of data whose entries are random numbers sampled from some specific distribution. Such arrays arise naturally in many areas of mathematics, statistics, as well as in natural sciences. The key to understanding the properties of a matrix is determining its spectral characteristics such as eigenvalues and eigenvectors. The research of the PI provided new information on typical spectral characteristics of a random matrix. In particular, a novel geometric method developed by him jointly with Vershynin allowed to prove delocalization properties of eigenvectors which are valuable in statistics and in modeling phenomena in quantum mechanics. The results of the PI on invertibility of large square sparse random matrices obtained by the PI jointly with Basak are of importance in computer science since they allow to estimate the errors arising in computations involving such matrices.
The research of the PI in geometric functional analysis was devoted to studying high-dimensional convex bodies which are sets of multidimensional data satisfying a number of inequalities. Such sets arise in numerous computational problems, especially in those involving the optimization. The PI's research was concentrated around the possibility of approximating complicated convex bodies by other bodies of a simpler structure. The results of this research have direct implications on the computational complexity of optimization problems involving convex bodies and on the necessity of randomized algorithms for their solution.


Broader impact of the PI's research.


The research on eigenvectors of random matrices is of importance for quantum physics as such matrices are used as models of excited heavy nuclei. The results on the condition number of sparse random matrices has applications in computer science and signal processing since the sparse random matrices are among the most frequently used tools in these areas, and the condition number controls the rate of convergence of many algorithms applied there. The results on the concentration of random determinants provide the error bounds for computer science algorithms used in the study of large networks. The results on complexity of high-dimensional convex bodies obtained by the PI show that an efficient computational description of those bodies can be hard to achieve.
The PI was involved in a number of activities related to the dissemination of the research results obtained within the funded project, teaching the younger generation of researchers and exposing graduate students and beginning researchers to the forefront of the  mathematical research. In particular, he has given more than 10 invited talks at international conferences on the results of his research in the last 3 years. The PI has organized a special semester at the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute (MSRI, Berkeley) which provided an opportunity for young researchers to learn about the cutting edge developments in geometric functional analysis and interact with the leading specialists in this field. The PI has organized a one week workshop on geometric functional analysis at Texas A&M University which included 4 series of lectures given by the leading experts in the area as well as shorter presentations given by younger researchers. The PI has given a course on delocalization of eigenvectors of random matrices in the framework of the special PCMI program on random matrix theory. These lectures were attended by close to a hundred graduate students and young researchers.
